------=_NextPart_000_0267_01CB2755.3339A3B0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Colin,
 
This is precisely the point.  The issue is identification of what those
"sub-functions" are.  Specifically, in indirect encoding these must be
characterized by their relationships to other related phenomena (the CPPN is
particularly good for this).
 
This goes back to Chris Bishop's descriptions of the Bayesian inference
classifiers.
 
Ken Lloyd

  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Colin
Green
Sent: Monday, July 19, 2010 3:03 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [neat] Node-split mutation


  

On 19 July 2010 01:49, Ken Lloyd <kalloyd@...
<mailto:kalloyd%40wattsys.com> > wrote:
>
> When adding or splitting either connections or nodes, and especially when
these new features
> improve function, I wonder about what precisely the meaning of that
function is.  If it is a
> component of computation, for example, what role does it play?
>
> These become patterns that represent some underlying functionality, often
underdetermined (and
> then you have to do some addtional pattern matching to try and see what
they mean). In other
> words, these constructs are not just nodes and connections.

The entire network represents a function (that's the whole point) and
sub-structures represent sub-parts/functions of the wider function(s).
Bearing this in mind may help us in thinking through if certain types
of mutation would be useful or not - is this what you're getting at?

Cheers,

Colin
